intro: Acer hyrcanum f. vitosensis, commonly known as the Persian maple, is a rare and ornamental tree native to the Caucasus region. It is characterized by its distinctive, palmately lobed leaves that turn vibrant red in the autumn. The plant typically grows to a height of 5–10 meters and prefers well-drained, acidic soils. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and can be found in botanical gardens and specialized collections. Due to its limited natural range, it is considered a rare and endangered species in the wild.
